Scheme 1 Catalytic schemes for the upgrading of PHAs of diesel boiling range, represented by naphthalene as a model compound, into (A) BTX and (B) high-CN diesel [13,14,18,34]. The theoretical hydrogen consumption at each reaction step is given in parenthesis. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 TEM images of (a) NiSn, (b) NiW, (c) NiMo and (d) CoMo supported on a hybrid zeolite of BZ(10). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of H-Beta, H-ZSM-5 and metals supported on a hybrid zeolite of BZ(10). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 H2-TPR profiles of Ni, Sn and NiSn supported on a hybrid zeolite of BZ(10). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 NH3-TPD profiles of H-Beta, hybrid zeolites (BZs) and H-ZSM-5. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) Hydrogenation activities (AHYD ) of metals/γ-Al2O3 in tetralin hydrogenation at different reaction temperatures, and (b) BTX yields obtained from tetralin hydrocracking over various metals/H-Beta and H-Beta catalysts as functions of hydrogenation activity and reaction temperature (Total pressure=4MPa, H2/tetralin molar ratio=8.0 and WHSV=2h−1). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) Yield of alkylbenzenes (other than BTX), (b) BTX yield and (c) BTX distribution obtained from tetralin hydrocracking over NiSn-supported zeolite catalysts as a function of H-ZSM-5 content (Total pressure=4MPa, H2/tetralin molar ratio=8.0 and WHSV=2h−1). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Product yields obtained from tetralin hydrocracking over NiMo-S/BZ(10) catalyst as a function of reaction temperature (Total pressure=4MPa, H2/tetralin molar ratio=8.0 and WHSV=2h−1). diesel-boiling-range polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons Jaeuk Shin Youngseok Oh Yeseul Choi Jihye Lee Jung Kyoo Lee ⁎ Department of Chemical Engineering, Dong-A University, Busan 49315, Republic of Korea Department of Chemical Engineering Dong-A University Busan 49315 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Various metallic components (Ni, NiSn, NiW-S, CoMo-S and NiMo-S) with different hydrogenation (HYD) activities were supported on H-Beta or hybrid zeolites (BZ(x), where x denotes the weight percentage of H-ZSM-5 in the physical mixture of H-Beta and H-ZSM-5). These bifunctional catalysts were applied to the hydrocracking (HYC) of tetralin in a fixed-bed down-flow reactor at 4MPa as a model reaction for polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) conversion to high-value benzene, toluene, and xylenes (BTX). From the HYC of tetralin over the series of metals/H-Beta catalysts, it was found that CoMo-S/H-Beta and NiMo-S/H-Beta, whose metallic components show moderate activities in the HYD of tetralin, exhibit higher BTX yields than the other catalysts whose metals have excessively high or low HYD activities. However, these catalysts show limited BTX yield (∼47.3wt% at 425°C) owing to the large coproduction of alkylbenzenes other than BTX. When metals with moderate HYD activities are supported on the hybrid zeolites, the BTX yield is significantly enhanced by the effect of H-ZSM-5 in the dealkylation of alkylbenzenes into BTX. NiMo-S/BZ(10) provides a BTX yield of 54.3wt% and a total 1-ring aromatic yield as high as 63.8wt% (corresponding to 94.4% of the theoretical maximum of 67.6wt%) at 425°C. Therefore, the NiMo-S/BZ(10) catalyst, where the metallic and acidic functions and structural properties of the zeolite are well balanced, show promise as an HYC catalyst for the hydroconversion of PAHs into high-value BTX mixtures. Keywords Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons Tetralin hydrocracking BTX Sulfide metals H-Beta Hybrid zeolite H-ZSM-5 1 Introduction Of all the diesel-boiling-range products produced in oil refining and petrochemical plants, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), such as light cycle oil (LCO) from fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) and pyrolysis fuel oil (PFO) from naphtha cracking, are regarded as the lowest-value feedstocks for hydroprocessing units owing to their high aromatic contents. For example, the aromatic content of LCO can be as high as 80wt% with the two-ring aromatic content being over 70% [1–3]. The PAHs in LCO also exhibit poor ignition properties in diesel engines and thus low cetane numbers (CNs), and have unfavorable cold flow properties, high densities, and unusually high contents of sulfur and nitrogen compounds. For these reasons, the PAH content in the diesel pool is limited. Consequently, LCO is usually used as a blending stock in heavy fuel oils for viscosity adjustment [1,4,5]. However, both the demand for heavy fuel oil and its sulfur limit are expected to fall due to worldwide emission controls imposed as a response to environmental concerns [6,7]. Hence, there is an increasing need to upgrade surplus PAHs of diesel boiling range into high-value products by catalytic hydroconversion. For example, catalytic hydrocoversion of LCO has been extensively explored to produce fuels (diesel and gasoline) [2,8–24] or light aromatic hydrocarbons [3,5,25–31]. As illustrated in Scheme 1 , PAHs, represented by naphthalene, can be upgraded to diesel fuel components with higher CNs [2,8–19], or into high-value light aromatic hydrocarbons such as benzene, toluene, and xylene (BTX) for petrochemical raw materials [3,5,19,25–31]. For both options, the hydroconversion of PAHs to the desired products involves the consumption of large quantities of hydrogen [5,14,30,32], which has a significant impact on the economics of hydroprocessing units. Recently, however, upgrading PAHs by hydrogen addition has become more favorable than it ever has been owing to the decrease in hydrogen production costs commensurate with the decrease in natural gas prices originating from increased shale gas production [33]. Nonetheless, if we compare the theoretical hydrogen consumption for the two options in Scheme 1, high CN diesel production requires more hydrogen than BTX production. For example, naphthalene (CN=1) HYD to decalin (CN=36) requires 5mol of hydrogen per mole of naphthalene. To further increase the product CN, the two decalin rings have to be consecutively opened to butyl cyclohexane (CN=46), and then further to 2-methyl-nonane (CN=54), 5-methyl-nonane (CN=50), or 3-ethyl-octane (CN=47), which consume 6 and 7mol of hydrogen, respectively (Scheme 1B). The ring-opening of tetralin (CN=10) gives alkylbenzenes with a limited CN increase. Furthermore, the development of a catalytic process that affords high yields of ring-opened high-CN products with high selectivity remains a challenge. In contrast, BTX production from naphthalene via partial hydrogenation (HYD) of naphthalene into tetralin, ring opening of tetralin to yield alkylbenzenes [13,34] and subsequent hydrocracking (HYC) of alkylbenzenes consumes only 4–5mol of hydrogen, as shown in Scheme 1A. Therefore, BTX production from PAHs of diesel boiling range presents a more economically viable route since the theoretical hydrogen consumption of this process is low and the value of BTX is higher than that of diesel blending stock. Since LCO has a moderately high contents of sulfur and nitrogen compounds as well as very high contents of 2- and 3-ring aromatics, a two-step hydroconversion process consisting of hydrotreating (HDT) and subsequent HYC, with efficient control of the heat generated and chemical equilibrium involved, is favored for BTX production from LCO [5,25,30]. Scheme 1A illustrates the reaction pathway with naphthalene as a model LCO compound. Naphthalene is hydrogenated to tetralin during the HDT of LCO, and the naphthenic ring of tetralin is hydrocracked to yield BTX. For a high per-pass yield of BTX, it is important to convert naphthalene into tetralin with high selectivity and conversion in the HDT step since complete HYD of naphthalene into decalin will lead to high yield of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) and naphtha with additional hydrogen consumption in the subsequent HYC step [5]. Similarly, selective HYC of the naphthenic ring of tetralin to BTX should proceed with a minimal conversion of tetralin back into naphthalene or into LPG and naphtha via decalin in the HYC step [30]. Thus, the operating conditions and catalyst design for HDT/HYC of LCO for BTX production should be different from those practiced in the conventional HDT/HYC of vacuum gas oils (VGOs), where pseudo-complete HYD of the aromatic compounds in the VGOs and high levels of conversion are preferred under high total pressure (∼180bar) to obtain high yields of jet fuel and diesel with ultra-low sulfur contents and good ignition properties. However, the HDT/HYC of LCO for BTX production has to be conducted under a moderate hydrogen pressure with HDT/HYC catalysts rationally designed for high BTX yields. Recently, various bifunctional HYC catalysts have been assessed for the HYC of PAHs into BTX. In these studies, different metallic components such as Co(or Mo)-Sn [28], NiMo [35], Ni2P [29], Ni [5], NiSn [30], and Co-Mo [30,31] were supported on zeolites and used for the direct HYC of naphthalene [29], 1-methyl naphthalene [35] and tetralin [5,30–32] as model feeds. As the acidic zeolite component, zeolite H-Beta afforded a higher yield of BTX and much more selective HYC behavior than other zeolite structures such as USY [28,29], ZSM-5 [29], and mordenite [31]. However, the per-pass yields of BTX from tetralin HYC in these studies were far below the theoretical maximum yield (67.6wt%) estimated from Scheme 1A assuming an equimolar mixture of BTX in the product [5]. This could be ascribed to 1) the poor design of the HYC catalysts in terms of metallic and acidic functions, and 2) poor selectivity for the desired product, resulting in coproduction of alkylbenzenes other than BTX from tetralin HYC [30], which is related to the structural and acidic properties of the zeolites in the HYC catalysts. Herein, we report rational design approaches for the preparation of a bifunctional HYC catalyst for the hydroconversion of PAHs into BTX with high selectivity and yield. A series of HYC catalysts were designed to counteract the above issues by 1) optimizing the metallic functions in terms of HYD activity, and 2) the introduction of hybrid zeolite systems comprising mixtures of zeolite H-Beta (12-MR) and ZSM-5 (10-MR) with different component ratios. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts Various metallic components including Ni, NiSn, CoMo, NiMo, and NiW were supported on H-Beta (SiO2/Al2O3 =38.0 or 75.0, Zeolyst) and hybrid zeolites by wet impregnation. The hybrid zeolites were prepared by physical mixing of H-Beta and HZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 =30, Zeolyst) with different HZSM- 5 contents and are denoted as BZ(x) hereafter, where x indicates the HZSM-5 content in wt%. Zeolite-supported Ni and NiSn catalysts with Ni and Sn contents of 5wt% and 3wt%, respectively, were prepared according to a literature method [30] with nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O) and tin chloride dihydrate (SnCl2·2H2O) as the metal precursors. The NiSn was supported on BZ(x) (x =10, 20, and 38.5) to study the effect of HZSM-5 content in the hybrid zeolites on the HYC of tetralin. To prepare zeolite-supported sulfide-metal catalysts, CoMo (Co=3wt% and Mo=8wt%), NiMo (Ni=3wt% and Mo=8wt%), and NiW (Ni=2.7wt% and W=19wt%) were also supported on H-Beta and BZ(x) by wet impregnation using cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O), nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O), ammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O), and ammonium metatungstate ((NH4)6H2W12O40·5H2O). The metal-impregnated catalysts were dried at room temperature and then at 80°C in air overnight. After drying, the catalysts were calcined at 500°C in air for 3h. For comparison testing of the different metals in tetralin HYD, they were also supported on γ-Al2O3 (Alfa Aesar, BET surface area=255m2/g, total pore volume=1.14cc/g) using the same procedure as that used for the preparation of the corresponding HYC catalysts described above. All the catalysts used in this study are listed in Table 1 along with their compositions. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The catalysts were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), temperature programmed reduction (TPR), temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD), and pulse chemisorption of H2. XRD patterns were obtained using a Rigaku Miniflex 600 with a Cu Kα X-ray source of wavelength 1.54Å. Measurement was performed using a scan range 5–80° with a step width of 0.02° and scan speed of 1°/min. TEM images were obtained using a JEM-2010 (JEOL, Japan). TPR and pulse H2 chemisorption analysis of the zeolite-supported Ni and NiSn catalysts were conducted using a BEL-CAT instrument (BEL Japan, Inc.) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For TPR, the oxide form of calcined Ni and NiSn catalysts were heated from 50 to 700°C at a constant rate of 10°C/min in 5% H2/Ar gas. For the pulse H2 chemisorption, the catalysts were oxidized and reduced at 450°C and then cooled to 50°C. H2 adsorption measurements were taken until the sample reached adsorption equilibrium at 50°C. The amount of H2 consumed in the TPR and the H2 uptake in the pulse H2 chemisorption were calculated using ChemMaster software. NH3-TPD analysis was also conducted using a BEL-CAT instrument. NH3 desorption was performed in the temperature range 100–700°C at constant heating rate of 10°C/min under He gas flow. The amount of NH3 desorbed from the acid sites was measured using ChemMaster software. 2.3 Catalytic activity tests 2.3.1 HYC of tetralin The HYC tests were carried out in a fixed-bed down-flow micro-reactor equipped with an electrical furnace, an HPLC pump, a back-pressure regulator, and mass flow controllers. The reaction pressure was set at 4MPa and the reaction temperature was varied in increasing mode over the range 375–450°C. In a typical reaction test, the catalyst (typically 0.58g) was pelletized and sieved into 250–500μm fractions and loaded into a stainless steel reactor (3/8” o.d.), where pressure drop and intraparticle diffusion limitation are negligible [36]. The upper space of the catalyst bed was filled with glass beads (1–1.25mm) so that the feed stream was preheated and well distributed down the reactor before entering the catalyst bed. Prior to the HYC of tetralin, catalysts were pretreated in situ in the reactor as follows: The zeolite-supported Ni and NiSn HYC catalysts were dried at 450°C in He flow for 2h. After cooling to room temperature, the catalysts were reduced at 450°C (ramping rate of 5°C/min) for 1h in H2 flow (60cc/min) under atmospheric pressure. After reduction, the reactor was cooled to 120°C and the reaction feed mixture was introduced into the reactor. The reactor pressure was raised to 4MPa followed by increasing the reactor temperature to the desired temperature. The tetralin was fed into the reactor using an HPLC pump at a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 2.0h−1 at a H2/tetralin molar ratio of 8 (corresponding to the volumetric ratio of 1315mL/mL high enough to eliminate the external mass transfer limitation as shown in Fig. S1)[37]. Unlike the Ni and NiSn catalysts, the zeolite-supported CoMo, NiMo, and NiW HYC catalysts were presulfided before the reaction tests. The catalyst was dried at 150°C for 1h in He flow (20 cc/min) in the reactor. After drying, the catalyst was sulfided in situ by introducing a sulfur-containing feed (10vol% dimethyl disulfide (DMDS) dissolved in a 1:1 (v/v) toluene/1,2,4-trimethylbenzene mixture) at WHSV=15.4h−1 and H2 (50.5cc/min) at 120°C under a pressure of 3.2MPa. The sulfidation was carried out at 400°C (ramping rate of 5°C/min) for 2h. After sulfidation, the reactor was cooled to 120°C and the pressure was raised to 4MPa. Then, the sulfidation feed was switched to a tetralin feed containing 100ppm of dimethyl sulfide (DMS). The tetralin HYC test was conducted following the same procedure as that described above. The reaction product stream was introduced to an on-line liquid-gas separator (operated at 273K) with a liquid sampling port. Steady-state was assumed after at least 4h of time-on-stream (TOS) at the designated reaction temperature, after which the liquid product from the separator bottom was collected for 2h and analyzed by off-line gas chromatography-flame ionization detector (GC-FID) employing an HP-INNOWax capillary column (60m×0.32mm×0.5μm). GC-mass spectrometry (MS) (Agilent 5973) coupled to a GC-FID (Agilent 6890) equipped with a DB-1ms capillary column (30m×0.25mm×0.25μm) was used to confirm the GC-FID peaks. The gas product from the separator overhead was analyzed by on-line GC-FID employing an HP Plot-Q capillary column (60m×0.32mm×0.5μm). 2.3.2 HYD of tetralin The γ-Al2O3-supported metal catalysts were pelletized and sieved into 250–500μm fractions. The sieved catalysts (typically 0.58g) were loaded in the reactor and subjected to the same pretreatment procedures as those for the corresponding HYC catalysts described above. After catalyst reduction or sulfidation, the reactor temperature was decreased to 120°C, and the same tetralin feed (for the supported Ni and NiSn catalysts) or sulfur-containing feed (for the sulfide catalysts) as those used in the HYC of tetralin was introduced into the reactor using an HPLC pump at WHSV=2h−1 and a H2/tetralin molar ratio of 8. The reactor pressure was raised to 4MPa followed by the reactor temperature being raised to the required temperature in the 350–450°C range. The liquid and gas products were analyzed by the same methods as those described above for the HYC of tetralin. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Properties of the catalysts Fig. 1 shows representative TEM images of different metals supported on the hybrid zeolite BZ(10). The reduced metal particles in NiSn/BZ(10) as shown in Fig. 1a are 9–15nm in size. In the TEM images of calcined BZ(10)-supported CoMo, NiMo, and NiW in Fig. 1b–d, respectively, particles 5–15nm in size are dispersed in the catalysts. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of the BZ(10)-supported HYC catalysts employed in this study. In the reduced NiSn supported catalysts, Ni and Sn are mostly present as Ni-Sn intermetallic phases such as Ni3Sn and Ni3Sn2, which is in agreement with previous reports [30,38]. Ni-Sn intermetallic phases are also indicated by the XRD patterns of the other supported-NiSn HYC catalysts (Fig. S2). The XRD patterns of the calcined CoMo, NiMo, and NiW catalysts all show metal oxides with crystalline phases, as marked in Fig. 2 [39–42]. The H2-TPR profile of NiSn/BZ(10) is displayed in Fig. 3 alongside those of Ni/BZ(10) and Sn/BZ(10), and the corresponding H2 consumptions are listed in Table 2 . In the TPR profile of Ni/BZ(10), H2 consumption (0.4μmol/gcat) occurs in two broad temperature ranges, i.e., 250–425 and 425–600°C, corresponding to the reduction of NiO particles that interact weakly with the zeolite support and those that interact more strongly with the zeolite to form chemical oxides such as surface layers of silicate-type compounds, respectively [43,44]. Sn/BZ(10) exhibits a small hydrogen consumption (0.10μmol/gcat) in the high-temperature range 475–630°C. Conversely, H2 consumption over the NiSn/BZ(10) catalyst occurs at a much lower and narrower temperature range (300–500°C) than that over Ni/BZ(10) and Sn/BZ(10). Furthermore, the amount of H2 consumed (0.68μmol/gcat) in the reduction of NiSn/BZ(10) is much larger than the sum of the amounts for Ni/BZ(10) and Sn/BZ(10). This suggests that the reducibility of Ni and Sn oxides is enhanced by the formation of Ni-Sn-O x species, which are reduced to intermetallic Ni-Sn compounds with various Ni/Sn ratios [38,45,46]. The H2 uptake over NiSn/BZ(10) is much lower than that over Ni/BZ(10) since Ni and Sn are present as intermetallic Ni3Sn and Ni3Sn2 phases, which are known to have very low activity for H2 dissociation [45]. The NH3-TPD profiles of H-Beta, H-ZSM-5, and their hybrids BZ(10), BZ(20), and BZ(38.5) employed as the zeolite components in the HYC catalysts are compared in Fig. 4 . The quantified amounts of weak and strong acid sites and the maximum temperatures (TM) of the corresponding desorption peaks are given in Table 3 . The amounts of both weak and strong acid sites and the value of TM increase with H-ZSM-5 content due to the higher acidity of H-ZSM-5 than that of H-Beta. The amount of strong acid sites and TM for H-Beta are 0.11mmol/g and 335°C, while those for H-ZSM-5 are 0.38mmol/g and 393°C, respectively. 3.2 Effect of the HYD activities of the H-beta-supported metals The HYD activity of the metal catalyst is a critical factor for a high per-pass BTX yield in the HYC of tetralin due to the chemical equilibrium involved, as shown in Scheme 1A. In order to assess the HYD activities of the different metals and their effects on the HYC of tetralin, they were supported on the low-acidity γ-Al2O3 and tested in the HYD of tetralin under the same reaction conditions as those used for HYC. As shown in Fig. 5 a, the results of tetralin HYD (Fig. S3) were used to compare the HYD activities of the metals in terms of decalin formation rate using Eq. (1): (1) AHYD (inmol/hg-cat)= Ft × Xt × Sd (%)/100 where Ft, Xt , and Sd are the molar feed rate of tetralin, tetralin conversion (0≤ Xt ≤1), and decalin selectivity (%) in the product, respectively. The AHYD values of the metals are in the order Ni>NiSn>NiW-S>NiMo-S>CoMo-S, and decrease with increasing reaction temperature owing to the chemical equilibrium involved in the exothermic HYD of tetralin [9,47,48]. The order of HYD activities of the sulfide metals are in agreement with previous reports on HYC catalysts [9]. The metals were then supported on H-Beta to study the effects of the HYD activity of the metallic components of the catalysts on the HYC of tetralin. Fig. 5b shows the BTX yields obtained over different HYC catalysts at different temperatures as a function of HYD activity. When the acidity of the bifunctional HYC catalyst is fixed (i.e., all metals supported on H-Beta (SiO2/Al2O3 =75.0)), the BTX yield increases to a maximum followed by subsequent decrease with the increasing AHYD of the catalyst, suggesting that the metallic component of an HYC catalyst should have an appropriate HYD activity to afford a high per-pass yield of BTX [30]. The BTX yields over both unmodified H-Beta with almost zero AHYD and Ni/H-Beta with the highest AHYD are very low at all temperatures. The BTX yield increases and the maximum yield shifts towards the low AHYD region as the reaction temperature increases since the cracking of the naphthenic ring of tetralin is favored and the HYD of tetralin is suppressed due to unfavorable thermodynamic equilibrium at high temperature. Overall, the HYC catalysts containing sulfide metals with lower AHYD values show higher BTX yields in the range 46.0–47.4wt% at 425°C than those of the other catalysts. However, the yields of BTX over the sulfide metal catalysts are still far below the theoretical yield of 67.6wt% [5,30], suggesting that there is significant scope for improvement of the HYC catalysts. Table 4 displays detailed product distributions obtained from the HYC of tetralin over the different HYC catalysts. In the reaction temperature range 400–425°C, tetralin conversion is >98% over all the catalysts. The LPG products are formed in larger yields over NiSn/H-Beta and NiW-S/H-Beta catalysts (whose metallic components exhibit rather high AHYD ) compared with those over NiMo-S/H-Beta and CoMo-S/H-Beta catalysts. BTX distribution is in the order B>T>X over all the HYC catalysts. It is noteworthy that there are rather high yields of alkylbenzenes other than BTX over all the HYC catalysts. These alkylbenzenes include ethylbenzene, ethyltoluene, propylbenzene, trimethylbenzenes, butylbenzene, and tetramethylbenzenes, and their yields are as high as 12–25wt% in total, as shown in Table 4. The total yields of BTX and alkylbenzenes over CoMo-S/H-Beta and NiMo-S/H-Beta are 65–67wt%, which approaches the theoretical maximum BTX yield of 67.6wt% expected from tetralin HYC [5]. This indicates that sulfide metals supported on H-Beta are highly selective in the ring-opening HYC of tetralin under the moderate total pressure of 4MPa. In order to further increase the per-pass yield of BTX, however, the HYC catalysts should be improved in such a way as to promote the conversion of those alkylbenzenes into BTX, which could be achieved by modifying the structural and acidic properties of their zeolitic supports. 3.3 HYC of tetralin over metals supported on hybrid zeolites 3.3.1 Effect of H-ZSM-5 content in hybrid zeolites As discussed above, metals supported on H-Beta exhibit high selectivity in the ring-opening of tetralin but show limited BTX yields owing to the large coproduction of alkylbenzenes other than BTX, which then have to be converted into BTX by dealkylation. For this purpose, NiSn was supported on hybrid BZ(x) zeolites (where x =0, 10, 20, 38.5, and 100) and assessed in the HYC of tetralin. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the alkylbenzene yields decrease with increasing H-ZSM-5 content and reaction temperature. For all the reaction temperatures, the yield of alkylbenzenes decreases substantially with the H-ZSM-5 content up to 20wt% followed by slight decreases with further increases in the H-ZSM-5 content. Conversely, the BTX yields increase significantly with H-ZSM-5 content in the HYC catalyst, as seen in Fig. 6b. The BTX yields are highest at H-ZSM-5 contents of 20 and 10wt% at 375 and 400–425°C, respectively. Thus, it is obvious that the addition of H-ZSM-5 facilitates the conversion of alkylbenzenes into BTX by dealkylation [49], and thereby enhances the per-pass yield of BTX from the HYC of tetralin. The BTX yield also increases with reaction temperature owing to enhanced cracking at acid sites with high temperature when the H-ZSM-5 content is less than ∼50wt% in the hybrid zeolites. The enhancement in the BTX yield with the addition of H-ZSM-5 could be ascribed to the high dealkylation activity of the 10-MR pore structure of H-ZSM-5 compared to that of the 12-MR H-Beta [49]. When NiSn is loaded onto hybrid BZ(x) zeolites prepared with the more acidic H-Beta (SiO2/Al2O3 =38.0), the BTX yield decreases significantly, mainly owing to the decreased liquid product yields and increased gaseous product yields (Fig. S4) caused by over-cracking on the hybrid zeolites with higher acidity (Fig. S5 and Table S1). Hence, hybrid zeolites comprising H-Beta with moderate acidity and H-ZSM-5 with high dealkylation activity should be used to obtain high BTX yields in tetralin HYC. As shown in Fig. 6c, the selectivity for BTX components in the liquid product is in the order B>T>X over the NiSn/H-Beta, NiSn/BZ(10), NiSn/BZ(20), and NiSn/BZ(38.5) catalysts, but T>B>X over the NiSn/H-ZSM-5 catalyst. It is also interesting to note that the selectivity for xylene in the BTX product increases with increasing H-ZSM-5 content in the HYC catalyst. Enhanced xylene selectivity upon 10-MR H-ZSM-5 addition to 12-MR H-Beta and H-mordenite has also been observed in the conversion of heavy reformates [49,50]. The detailed results from the HYC of tetralin over supported NiSn catalysts are presented in Table 5 . The BTX yields over NiSn/BZ(10) and NiSn/H-Beta are 52.8 and 44.7wt%, while the yields of alkylbenzenes are 8.8 and 14.5wt% at 425°C, respectively. When the H-ZSM-5 content is increased from 10 to 20, 38.5, and 100wt% for NiSn/BZ(20), NiSn/BZ(38.5), and NiSn/H-ZSM-5, respectively, the yields of both BTX and alkylbenzenes decrease, while the yield of LPG products is substantially increased. This increased cracking activity at high H-ZSM-5 contents could be due to the increased acidity of the zeolite support, as shown in Fig. 4. Over the NiSn/H-ZSM-5 catalyst, which has the highest-acidity zeolite matrix, the BTX yield is slightly larger than that over NiSn/H-Beta, but the LPG yield is as high as 49.1wt% at 400°C due to the severe HYC that accompanies large hydrogen consumption. The BTX content in the liquid product also increases with H-ZSM-5 content and reaches 90.3wt% over NiSn/H-ZSM-5 at 425°C, mainly due to the high dealkylation activity of 10-MR H-ZSM-5 compared to that with 12-MR zeolites. Hence, the enhanced BTX yield and xylene selectivity with H-ZSM-5 addition could be ascribed to it facilitating the dealkylation of alkylbenzenes as described above, and to its activity in the disproportionation of toluene and trimethylbenzenes as well as transalkylation between benzene/toluene and trimethylbenzenes [49,50]. However, the optimum H-ZSM-5 content of the hybrid zeolites should be determined after further study on the HYC of actual process feedstocks such as LCO, which has a significantly different molecular structure distribution and composition complexity to that of the model compound tetralin. 3.3.2 Effect of metals on hybrid zeolites As shown above, the BTX yield from the HYC of tetralin is increased significantly when the NiSn is supported on a hybrid zeolite comprising H-ZSM-5 and H-Beta at 10 and 90wt%, respectively (i.e., BZ(10)). Consequently, in the final experiments of this study, different metals having different tetralin HYD activities (AHYD ) were supported on BZ(10) and assessed for the HYC of tetralin. As listed in Table 6 , all the BZ(10)-supported HYC catalysts show enhanced BTX yields compared to those of the corresponding H-Beta-supported HYC catalysts. At 425°C, for example, the BTX yields over CoMo-S/BZ(10) and NiMo-S/BZ(10) are increased to 52.1 and 54.3wt%, respectively, from 47.4 and 47.1wt% over CoMo-S/H-Beta and NiMo-S/H-Beta, respectively. Furthermore, the alkylbenzene yields over CoMo-S/BZ(10) and NiMo-S/BZ(10) are decreased to 9.9 and 9.5wt%, respectively, from 19.5wt% and 18.2wt% over CoMo-S/H-Beta and NiMo-S/H-Beta, respectively. Of the sulfide metal-loaded catalysts, NiW-S/BZ(10) shows the lowest BTX yield and the highest yield of gaseous LPG products due to the high HYD activity of NiW-S compared to those of CoMo-S and NiMo-S. CoMo-S/BZ(10) affords high yields of heavy aromatics such as C10 aromatics, naphthalenes, and C11 + aromatics, possibly due to the low HYD activity of CoMo-S. Among the HYC catalysts, NiMo-S/BZ(10), whose metallic component exhibits moderate HYD activity, shows the largest BTX yield, which is as high as 54.3wt% (at 425°C) corresponding to ∼80% of the theoretical yield. Fig. 7 a and b shows the product yields over NiMo-S/BZ(10) as a function of reaction temperature. As the reaction temperature increases the yields of benzene, alkylbenzenes, and naphtha decrease, while those of toluene, xylene, and gaseous products increase. Among the gaseous products, C3 species are the most abundant, followed by C4 and C2 species, as is typically observed in the HYC of hydrocarbons. The total BTX and alkylbenzenes yields, i.e., the total 1-ring aromatics yields, derived from the HYC of tetralin over NiMo-S/BZ(10) are 65.0 and 63.8wt% at 400 and 425°C, respectively. As shown in Fig. 7a, these total 1-ring aromatics yields correspond to 94–96% of the theoretical BTX yield (67.6wt%) possible from the HYC of tetralin, indicating that the metallic and acidic functions and the zeolitic components in NiMo-S/BZ(10) are well balanced for converting tetralin into BTX with high selectivity and yield. As compared in Fig. 7b, the yields of cracked products (gas and naphtha products) are close to the theoretical yield of 32.4wt% when the reaction temperature is lower than 425°C, while non-selective over-cracking of tetralin occurs at 450°C to give rise to a higher yield of cracked products (37.4wt%) than the theoretical yield. The BTX product distribution over the NiMo-S/BZ(10) is in the order B>T>>X. The result of catalyst stability test over NiMo-S/BZ(10) is shown in Fig. S6. A slow but steady deactivation was observed after 36h of time on stream. Since the catalyst deactivation of hydrocracking of PAHs is mostly due to fouling by coke deposition [21], higher total pressure and H2/feed molar ratio than those employed in this study might be better implemented to retard catalyst deactivation. Hence, further optimization of the HYC catalyst and/or process conditions in order to achieve higher selectivity and yields of xylenes, and improve catalyst stability should be the focus of future studies, preferentially with actual process feedstocks such as LCO, to enhance product value and thereby improve the process economics of the hydroconversion of PAHs of diesel boiling range. 4 Conclusions In summary, the HYC of tetralin as a model reaction for the hydroconversion of PAHs into high value BTX was studied over bifunctional metal/zeolite catalysts having different HYD activities, acidities, and zeolite structures. When different metals (Ni, NiSn, CoMo-S, NiMo-S and NiW-S) having different activities in the HYD of tetralin were supported on H-Beta, it was found that HYC catalysts containing metals with a moderate HYD activities (CoMo-S, NiMo-S) showed higher per-pass yields of BTX than the HYC catalysts containing metals with high HYD activity (Ni, NiSn, and NiW-S) or the monofunctional H-Beta. However, these catalysts showed limited BTX yields (∼70% of the theoretical yield) due to the large coproduction of alkylbenzenes other than BTX. To further enhance the BTX yield by promoting the conversion of alkylbenzenes into BTX, H-ZSM-5 was mixed with H-Beta at various weight fractions (10, 20, and 38.5wt%) to form hybrid zeolites. When NiMo-S, which has a moderate HYD activity, was supported on the BZ(10) hybrid zeolite, the BTX yield at 425°C was 54.3wt% (about 80.3% of the theoretical yield). This is a significant improvement on the 47.1wt% obtained over NiMo-S/H-Beta, and is due to the enhanced dealkylation of alkylbenzenes to BTX over H-ZSM-5 owing to its high acidity and small pore size. Thus, NiMo-S/BZ(10), in which the metallic and acidic functions and structural properties are well balanced, could be used as a selective HYC catalyst in the hydroconversion of PAHs process for high-value BTX production. coredata.dc:description: Various metallic components (Ni, NiSn, NiW-S, CoMo-S and NiMo-S) with different hydrogenation (HYD) activities were supported on H-Beta or hybrid zeolites (BZ(x), where x denotes the weight percentage of H-ZSM-5 in the physical mixture of H-Beta and H-ZSM-5). These bifunctional catalysts were applied to the hydrocracking (HYC) of tetralin in a fixed-bed down-flow reactor at 4MPa as a model reaction for polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) conversion to high-value benzene, toluene, and xylenes (BTX). From the HYC of tetralin over the series of metals/H-Beta catalysts, it was found that CoMo-S/H-Beta and NiMo-S/H-Beta, whose metallic components show moderate activities in the HYD of tetralin, exhibit higher BTX yields than the other catalysts whose metals have excessively high or low HYD activities. However, these catalysts show limited BTX yield (∼47.3wt% at 425°C) owing to the large coproduction of alkylbenzenes other than BTX. When metals with moderate HYD activities are supported on the hybrid zeolites, the BTX yield is significantly enhanced by the effect of H-ZSM-5 in the dealkylation of alkylbenzenes into BTX. NiMo-S/BZ(10) provides a BTX yield of 54.3wt% and a total 1-ring aromatic yield as high as 63.8wt% (corresponding to 94.4% of the theoretical maximum of 67.6wt%) at 425°C. Therefore, the NiMo-S/BZ(10) catalyst, where the metallic and acidic functions and structural properties of the zeolite are well balanced, show promise as an HYC catalyst for the hydroconversion of PAHs into high-value BTX mixtures.
coredata.dc:title: Design of selective hydrocracking catalysts for BTX production from diesel-boiling-range polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons
